tgt_text.744: Une seule, digne du flambeau nuptial, fut noblement parjure* envers un pre criminel :
tgt_text.745: son nom ne prira jamais. Lve-toi, dit-elle  son jeune poux, lve-toi, de peur qu'une main, dont tu ne te dlies pas, n'ternise ton sommeil :
tgt_text.746: fuis mon pre et mes terribles surs;
tgt_text.747: comme des lionnes attaches  leur proie, chacune, hlas!
tgt_text.748: gorge en ce moment sa victime.
tgt_text.749: Non, comme elles, je ne saurais ni te frapper ni te retenir.
tgt_text.750: Que mon pre me charge de chanes pour avoir eu pitic de mon poux, qu'il me relgue au fond des dserts de la Libye!
tgt_text.751: Fuis, o tes pas, o les vents te porteront;
tgt_text.752: la nuit et Vnus nous favorisent;
tgt_text.753: fuis sous d'heureux auspices, ne m'oublie pas, et grave un jour quelques regrets sur ma tombe.
tgt_text.754: A NOBL.Je plains celle qui n'ose se livrer aux jeux de l'amour, ni adoucir ses peines dans le vin;
tgt_text.755: toujours ple et tremblante  la voix cruelle dun tuteur.
tgt_text.756: L'enfant ail de Cythre a ravi ta corbeille,  Nobul;
tgt_text.757: la toile et tous les travaux de Minerve sont oublis pour le jeune Hbrus.Meilleur cavalier que Bellrophon lui-mme, sans rival au ceste et  la course, il baigne dans les eaux du Tibre ses paules frottes d'huile :
tgt_text.758: jamais sa flche n'a manqu le cerf qui fuit perdu dans la plaine, ni son pieu le sanglier cach sous d'pais halliers.A LA FONTAINE DE BANDUSIE .Fontaine de Bandusie, plus claire que le cristal, digne des libations d'un vin pur, demain je t'offre avec des fleurs un jeune chevreau;
tgt_text.759: son front o lon voit poindre les premires cornes, sapprte aux amours et aux combats;
tgt_text.761: lanimal ptulant rougira tes eaux limpides.
tgt_text.762: Les jeux de l'ardente Canicule ne sauraient teffleurer;
tgt_text.763: tu procures aux bufs fatigus du joug et aux troupeaux errants une dlicieuse fracheur.
tgt_text.764: Et toi aussi, Bandusie, tu seras une fontaine clbre;
tgt_text.765: je chanterai le chne vert pench sur la grotte d'o jaillissent tes eaux murmurantes.
tgt_text.766: SUR LE RETOUR DAUGUSTE*,Romains, celui que l'on disait avoir pay de sa vie des lauriers cueillis sur les pas dHercule, Csar, revient parmi nous, vainqueur de lEspagne.
tgt_text.767: Que celle dont le plus grand des poux fait la gloire aille sacquitter envers les dieux;
tgt_text.768: suivez-la, le front ceint de pieuses bandelettes, surs du hros, et vous, mres dont les fils sont de retour.
tgt_text.769: Pour vous, qui pleurez si jeune un poux ou un pre, pargnez-nous de sinistres paroles.Ce jour est pour moi un vrai jour de fle;
tgt_text.771: je ne craindrai plus la guerre civile elle fer des assassins,
tgt_text.772: Csar na pas quitt la terre.Va, jeune esclave, chercher des parfums, des couronnes, et de ce vin qui a vu la guerre des Marses 3, s'il en est chapp une amphore aux bandes de Spartacus 4.
tgt_text.773: Dis  la chanteuse Nra quelle se hte de nouer ses cheveux parfums de myrte.
tgt_text.774: Si son odieux portier veut te faire attendre, reviens.
tgt_text.775: Une tte qui blanchit n'aime plus le bruit et les querelles;
tgt_text.776: jaurais t moins patient, dans la chaleor de l'ge, sous le consulat de Planons .Femme du pauvre Ibycus, mets enfin un terme  tes dbauches et  tes infmes travaux;
tgt_text.777: quand la mort tappelle, cesse de jouer au milieu des jeunes filles, sombre nuage parmi de blanches toiles.
tgt_text.778: Ce qui sied  Pholo ne te sied plus, Chloris :
tgt_text.779: que ta fille, comme une bacchante agite par le bruit des timbales, force la maison des jeunes Romains;
tgt_text.780: qu'elle se joue autour de Nothus comme la biche amoureuse;
tgt_text.781: toi, vieille et ride, file la laine de, Lucrie*;
tgt_text.782: laisse pour les fuseaux, et la lyre, et les roses, et les joyeux festins o lon vide les tonneaux jusqu' la lie.A MCNE.Une tour d'airain, des portes de fer, dnormes chiens veillant sans relche, semblaient garantir Dana des tentatives de ses amants;
tgt_text.783: mais Jupiter et Vnus se rirent du gardien tremblant de celte beaut captive :
tgt_text.784: le chemin devait ire sur et facile pour un dieu chang en or.
tgt_text.785: Lor se glisse  travers les gardes, et, plus puissant que la foudre, il perce les rochers.
tgt_text.786: Si la maison d'Amphiaras* a pri, c'est l'or qui la plongea dans lablme;
tgt_text.787: avec lor, le roi de Macdoine 4 ouvrait les portes des villes, et minait la puissance des rois ses rivaux;
tgt_text.788: lor enchane les plus farouches corsaires.
tgt_text.789: Mais avec la fortune croissent les soucis et la soif d'acqurir.
tgt_text.790: Mcne, l'honneur des chevaliers, j'ai toujours craint d'le ver la tte et d'attirer les regards.
tgt_text.791: Plus on se refuse, plus les dieux nous accordent.
tgt_text.792: Transfuge du parti des riches, je passe joyeux et nu dans le camp de ceux qui ne dsirent rien;
tgt_text.793: pins libre et plus fier avec le peu que je possde, que si j'entassais dans mes greniers toutes les moissons de l'infatigable Apulien, pauvre au milieu de mes richesses.
tgt_text.794: Un ruisseau limpide, un bois de quelques arpents, des moissons fidles, me font un sort plus heureux que celui d'un opulent proconsul de la fertile Afrique.
tgt_text.795: Ce n'est pas pour moi que les abeilles de la Calabre dposent leur miel, que le vin de Formies vieillit dans lamphore, que les brebis de la Gaule nourrissent leurs paisses toisons;
tgt_text.796: mais j'ignore les tourments de la )>auvret, et si je voulais davantage, Mcne, tu me le donnerais.
tgt_text.797: En resserrant mes dsirs, je sais mieux tendre mon humble revenu que si je runissais au royaume de Crsus les plaines de la Phrygie.
tgt_text.799: heureux  qui, dune main conome, les dieux ont accord le ncessaire!
tgt_text.800: Noble rejeton de lantique Lamus 1 (car cest de lui que les premiers Lamias ont tir leur nom, et nos fidles annales font remonter votre race  ce fondateur de Formies, dont lempire stendit sur les rives marcageuses du Liris );
tgt_text.801: lius, demain un violent orage, venu du couchant, jonchera les bois de feuilles et le rivage dalgues inutiles, ou la corneille centenaire qui annonce la pluie m'aura tromp.
tgt_text.802: Mets  couvert ton bois sec, il en est temps encore :
tgt_text.803: demain lu offriras au dieu du foyer un vin pur et un porc de deux mois, an milieu de tes serviteurs libres pour un jour de leurs travaux.Faune, araanl des Nymphes fugitives, visite en dieu clment mon humble domaine, et que ton passage soit heureux pour tes jeunes lves de mes tables :
tgt_text.804: tous les ans je t'immole un chevreau,la coupe chre  Vnus te verse des flots de vin, et l'encens fume sur ton autel antique.
tgt_text.805: Quand les noues de dcembre ramnent ta fte, les troupeaux se jouent sur l'herbe touffue;
tgt_text.806: tout le village se rpand dans les prs, avec le buf oisif;
tgt_text.807: le loup se mle aux agneaux, sans les effrayer;
tgt_text.808: les bois sment leurs feuilles sur ton passage;
tgt_text.809: et le vigneron frappe d'un pied joyeux celte terre, qu'il a souvent maudite.A TELPHE.Tu nous parles du temps qui spare InachusdeCodrus, mort pour sa patrie, et des fils d'aque*, et des combats livrs sous les murs sacrs d'il ion;
tgt_text.810: mais  quel prix aurons-nous le vin de Ghio?
tgt_text.812: A quelle heure, et chez qui trouverons-nous bonne table et bon feu?
tgt_text.813: Tu n?en dis rien, lphe.Verse pour la lune nouvelle, esclave;
tgt_text.816: On peut remplir trois ou neuf fois les coupes;
tgt_text.817: le pote, amant des neuf surs, dans son dlire videra neuf fois la sienne;
tgt_text.818: mais les Grces demi-nues ont peur des querelles, et dfendent d'aller au del de trois.
tgt_text.820: O Sont les fltes de Brcynthe?
tgt_text.821: Que fait ce hautbois suspendu prs de la lyre muette?
tgt_text.824: Que le bruit de nos folies veille le jaloux Lycus, et la jeune voisine, si mal unie  ce vieil poux.
tgt_text.825: Ta noire chevelure,  Tlphe, tes yeux doux et brillants comme l'toUe du soir, attirent l'amoureuse Rhod;
tgt_text.826: et moi je languis, je brle pour ma Glycre.Ne vois-tu pas, Pyrrhus, le danger de ravir ma lionne de Gtulie ses petits?
tgt_text.827: Bientt, tu fuiras tremblant une lutte ingale, quand,  travers la foule des chasseurs, elle viendra te disputer le beau Narque;
tgt_text.828: combat terrible,  qui de vous deux doit rester cette proie 1
tgt_text.829: Et pendant que tu prpares tes flches rapides, qu'elle aiguise ses dents redoutables, on dit que le juge du combat foule la palme sous ses pieds nus, et abandonne au souffle caressant du zphyr les cheveux parfums qui flottent sur ses paules :
tgt_text.830: tel fut Nire', ou Ganymde ravi aux humides vallons de l'lda.
tgt_text.831: Amphore chrie, ne comme moi sous le consul Manlius , que lu portes dans ton sein la tristesse ou les jeux, les querelles, les folles amours, oue facile sommeil;
tgt_text.832: tu conserves un Massique de choix, digne de paratre en un si beau jour.
tgt_text.833: Viens, Corvinus 3 lordonne, viens lui verser ta vieille liqueur :
tgt_text.834: tout imbu quil est des maximes de Socrate, ne crois pas que son austrit te ddaigne;
tgt_text.835: on sait que le bon vin rchauffait souvent la vertu du vieux Caton.Tu fais aux caractres les plus rigides une douce violence;
tgt_text.836: tu dvoiles, en te jouant, les soucis et les secrtes penses du sage;
tgt_text.837: tu rveilles dans un cur abattu lesprance et la force;
tgt_text.838: avec toi, le pauvre lve la tte, et ne craint plus ni la colre des rois ni les pes.Que la riante Vnus, les Grces toujours unies, et le dieu du plaisir te fassent durer, la clart des flambeaux, jusqu l'heure o Phbus revient chasser les toiles.Gardienne des bois et des montagnes, vierge qui, trois fois invoque, exauces la jeune pouse dans les douleurs de l'enfantement, et la drobes  la mort, triple desse, je te consacre le pin qui domine mon toit champtre;
tgt_text.839: tous les ans je t'offrirai, sous son feuillage, un jeune sanglier qui dj cherche  frapper dun coup oblique.
tgt_text.840: Quand la lune reliait, lve au ciel tes mains suppliantes, lionne Phidyl, offre aux dieux Lares de l'encens, une truie avide, et des fruits de l'anne;
tgt_text.841: et ta vigne fconde ne sentira pas le souille mortel de lAuster, ni tes moissons la nielle sttile, ni tes jeunes agneaux la lourde haleine de la saison des fruits.
tgt_text.842: Laisse la victime choisie qui pat sur  Algide*, au-dessous des neiges, entre les chnes et les yeuses, ou qui grandit dans les pturages albains, teindre de son sang la hache des pontifes.
tgt_text.843: Tu nas pas besoin dgorger tant de brebis pour flchir les humbles dieux que tu couronnes de romarin et de myrte.
tgt_text.844: Si une main pure a touch l'autel, lorge sacr et le sel ptillant apaiseront les Lares irrits mieux que la plus riche offrande.
tgt_text.845: CONTRE LES VICES DU SICLE.Avec des richesses plus grandes que les trsors encore intacts de lArabie et de llnde, quand tu envahirais de tes vastes constructions les mers de Tyrrhne et dApulie, si l'intlexible destin appuie sur ton front superbe sa main de fer, tu ne pourras dgager ton me de la crainte, ni les pieds des lilels de la mort.
tgt_text.846: Plus heureux, dans ses dserts, le Scythe qui trane sur un chariot sa demeure errante!
tgt_text.847: Plus heureux le Gte sauvage  Leurs champs sans limites produisent une libre et commune moisson :
tgt_text.848: ils ne cultivent quun an le mme sol;
tgt_text.849: la tche de lun remplie, un autre lui succde et le fait jouir de ses travaux.
tgt_text.850: L, l'pouse nouvelle est douce  l'enfant qui n'a plus sa mre;
tgt_text.851: l, point de femme richement dote qui commande  un mari, et le menace de ses amants.
tgt_text.852: La plus belle dot, c'est la vertn des parents, l'horreur de l'adultre, un chaste respect de l'alliance jure :
tgt_text.853: l'infidlit est un crime, et la mort en est le prix.O toi, qui veux touffer nos guerres impies et nos fureurs civiles, si tu dsires qu'on lise un jour sur tes statues :
tgt_text.855: ose mettre un frein  la licence indompte.
tgt_text.856: Ta gloire est sre dans lavenir;
tgt_text.858: notre il jaloux hait la vertu vivante, et nos regrets l'appellent quand elle n'est plus.A quoi bon ces plaintes amres, si la hache ne coupe le mal dans sa racine?
tgt_text.859: Que peuvent de vaines lois, sans les murs;
tgt_text.860: si rien n'arrte lavidit du marchand, ni les feux de la zone torride, ni les barrires de neige et de glace;
tgt_text.861: si lart du matelot triomphe des mers en furie;
tgt_text.862: si la pauvret, devenue le plus grand des opprobres, ordonne de tout faire, de souffrir, et abandonne lpre sentier de la vertu?Portons au Capitole, o nous appellent les cris et les applaudissements de la foule, ou, dans la mer voisine, jetons ces perles, ces diamants, cet or inutile, principe de tous nos maux.
tgt_text.863: Si notre repentir est sincre, il faut touffer le germe de nos honteuses passions, et, par des gots plus mles, retremper nos mes amollies.
tgt_text.864: Le jeune Romain chancelle sur un coursier;
tgt_text.866: le cerceau des Grecs et les ds proscrits par la loi, voil les jeux o il excelle.
tgt_text.867: Et cependant un pre sars foi trompe son associ, son hte, son ami, et le dpouille pour hter la fortune de cet indigne hritier :
tgt_text.868: chaque jour accrot ses infmes richesses;
tgt_text.869: mais, au milieu de ses trsors, je ne sais quel vide se fait toujours sentir.A VNUS.Je plaisais nagure aux jeunes filles;
tgt_text.870: et j'ai servi, non sans gloire, sous les drapeaux de l'amour.
tgt_text.871: Aujourdhui je consacre  Vnus mes armes et le luth qui a fini ses campagnes;
tgt_text.872: je les suspends  sa gauche, aux murs de son temple :
tgt_text.873: quon y attache aussi les flambeaux, les leviers, et les haches, qui menaaient les portes fermes.Desse, qui tiens sous ton empire l'lle fortune de Chypre, et Mempfais o l'on ne vit jamais les neiges de la Thrace, reine des amours, touche seulement de ton fouet divin l'altire Ghlo.O mentrane,  Bacchus, ton souffle divin?
tgt_text.874: Dans quel bois, sous quel autre dsert m'emporte l'essor d'un esprit nouveau?
tgt_text.875: Quels rochers entendront ma voix lever la gloire ternelle de Csar au-dessus des astres, et l'introduire au conseil de Jupiter?
tgt_text.876: Tout sera sublime, tout sera nouveau dans mes chants.
tgt_text.877: Telle, au sommet des monts, la Bacchante  son-rveil, immobile, perdue, dcouvre au loin l'Hbre glac, la Thrace couverte de neige, et de Rhodope que foule un pied barbare.
tgt_text.878: Oh! dans mes courses vagabondes, que j'aime la rive escarpe et le bois solitaire 1 Dieu des Naades, dieu des Bacchantes, dont le bras puissant dracine les hauts frnes, rien de faible et de vulgaire, rien de mortel ne sortira de ma bouche!
tgt_text.879: C'est un doux pril,  Bacchus, de suivre le dieu qui se couronne de pampres verts.A GALATE.Que l'impie ait pour prsage le cri rpt de la/rsaie, une lice pleine, une louve rousse descendant des coteaux de Lanuyie, ou la femelle du renard avec ses petits;
tgt_text.880: et quun serpent interrompe son voyage, en passant comme une flche devant ses chevaux pouvants.
tgt_text.881: Mais, si je crains pour un ami, avant que loiseau prcurseur de l'orage regagne leau dormante des marais, vigilant augure, mes vux appelleront de l'Orient un corbeau favorable.Sois heureuse,  Galate, en quelque lieu que tu veuilles l'tre;
tgt_text.883: et que ni la corneille errante, ni le sinistre pivert ne s'oppose  ton dpart.
tgt_text.884: Vois cependant de quelle tempte nous menace le coucher dOrion :
tgt_text.885: je connais les vagues noires de lAdriatique, et la srnit perfide du zphyr.
tgt_text.886: Que les femmes, les enfants de nos ennemis, prouvent seuls les sourdes secousses de l'Autan qui slve, et le mugissement dune mer tnbreuse qui fait trembler ses rivages!Ainsi la blanche Europe osa se confier au taureau trompeur;
tgt_text.887: mais bientt, au milieu des cueils et des monstres qui peuplent l'abime, l'audacieuse plit.
tgt_text.888: Nagure, dans les prairies, elle cherchait des fleurs pour tresser la couronne promise aux Nymphes;
tgt_text.889: et,  la faible lueur des toiles, elle ne voit plus que le ciel et les eaux.
tgt_text.890: A peine a-t-elle touch la Crte aux cent villes :
tgt_text.892: scrie-t-elle, nom chri mpris par ta fille!
tgt_text.893: Doux et pieux devoirs, que j'ai trahis dans mon dlire!
tgt_text.896: C'est trop peu d'une mort pour une fille coupable.
tgt_text.897: Yeill-je quand je pleure ma honte?
tgt_text.898: Ou pure encore, suis-je le jouet dune vaine illusion, dun songe chapp la porte divoire?
tgt_text.899: Valait-il mieux traverser la mer immense, que de cueillir les fleurs nouvelles? Ah! si dans ce moment on livrait cet infme taureau  ma colre!
tgt_text.900: Je trouverais la force de le mettre en pices, de briser les cornes du monstre que j'ai trop aim.
tgt_text.901: Sans pudeur, jaf fui les dieux paternels;
tgt_text.903: O dieux, sil en est qui m'entendent, que ne suis-je errante et nue au milieu des lions!
tgt_text.904: Avant quune hideuse maigreur ait fltri mes joues, et dessch cette faible proie belle encore, je veux tre la pture des tigres. Misrable Europe 1 ton pre absent te crie :
tgt_text.906: Cet arbre, cette ceinture qui heureusement ne ta pas quitte, peuvent terminer ta vie;
tgt_text.907: ou si la mort lappelle sur la pointe aigu de ces cueils, va, lance-toi dans la tempte :
tgt_text.908: moins que tu n'aimes mieux, fille des rois, tourner les fuseaux pour une maltresse trangre, et servir de concubine  son poux!
tgt_text.909: Vnus l'coutait avec un perfide sourire, ayant prs delle son fils, appuy sur son arc dfendu.
tgt_text.910: Lorsqu'elle se fut assez joue de sa douleur :
tgt_text.911: Europe, lui dit-elle, retiens ces cris et ces transports de colre, quand l'odieux taureau te livrera ses cornes, pour les briser.
tgt_text.912: Tu ne sais pas tre lpouse du grand Jupiter?
tgt_text.916: parties du monde te devra son nom.
tgt_text.917: A LYD.Que faire de mieux, le jour consacr  Neptune?
tgt_text.918: Allons, Lyd, tire le ccube cach au fond du cellier, et force ta sagesse dans ses retranchements.
tgt_text.919: Tu vois le soleil qui dcline;
tgt_text.920: et, comme si les heures suspendaient leur vol, tu crains d'arracher  son repos une vieille amphore du consulat de Bibulus*
tgt_text.921: .Nous chanterons tour  tour, moi, Neptune et les vertes chevelures des Nrides, toi, sur ta lyre d'ivoire, Latone et les flches rapides de Diane :
tgt_text.922: nos derniers chants seront pour la desse qui rgne  Gnide, aux brillantes Gyclades, et qui vole  Paphos sur un char attel de cygnes.
tgt_text.923: La Nuit ne sera pas non plus oublie.A MCNE.
tgt_text.924: Descendant des rois d'trurie, Mcne, depuis longtemps je te rserve une amphore de vieux vin, avec des roses et des parfums pour tes cheveux.
tgt_text.925: Viens, que rien ne te retienne :
tgt_text.926: faut-il contempler toujours l'humide Tibur, les coteaux d'Esule*, et les monts du parricide Tlgon3?
tgt_text.927: Quitte les ennuis de lopulence, et ce palais dont le fate slve jusquaux nues;
tgt_text.928: laisse admirer  d'autres la fume, le luxe, le fracas de lheureuse Rome.
tgt_text.929: Le changement amuse quelquefois les riches;
tgt_text.930: et sous l'humble toit du pauvre, un repas frugal, sans pourpre ni tapis, dride leur front soucieux.Dj le pre4 dAndromde montre ses feux tincelants, Procyons fait sentir ses fureurs, le Lion rugit, et le soleil a ra men les jours arides.
tgt_text.931: Dj le ptre, avec son troupeau languissant, cherche fatigu l'ombre, les ruisseaux, les buissons du sauvage Sylvain;
tgt_text.932: et les vents dorment sur.la rive silencieuse.Toi, cependant, tu mdites les moyens d'assurer le bonheur de Rome;
tgt_text.933: ta pense inquite veut pntrer les projets des Sres, des Bactriens dompts par Cyrus, et des peuples du Tauas dchirs par la discorde.
tgt_text.934: La prudence des dieux couvre lavenir d'une nuit profonde, et rit du mortel qui s'agite dans ces tnbres.
tgt_text.935: Songe  rgler le prsent avec sagesse :
tgt_text.936: le reste suit son cours comme le fleuve qui, tantt renferm dans son lit, s'coule paisiblement vers la mer de Toscane, tantt, avec un fracas que rpte l'cho des monts et des forts voisines, roule les pierres, les arbres dracins, les troupeaux, les maisons, lorsque les torrents ont irrit ses eaux tranquilles.
tgt_text.937: .Celuil seul est heureux et matre de lui-mme, qui chaque soir peut se dire :
tgt_text.939: Demain que Jupiter charge le ciel de noirs nuages ou qu'il lclaire d'un soleil pur, le pass n'est plus  lui;
tgt_text.940: il ne peut changer ni dtruire ce qu'une fois l'heure fugitive a emport.
tgt_text.941: La fortune se complat dans le mal, et obstine  ses jeux bizarres, elle va portant son incertaine faveur, aujourdhui chez moi, demain chez un autre.
tgt_text.943: si elle dploie ses ailes rapides, je lui rends ses dons, et, menveloppant de ma vertu, j'pouse sans dot une honnte pauvret.
tgt_text.944: Que dautres, si la tempte mugit dans les mts, descendent  de misrables prires, et composent avec les dieux, pour que leurs richesses n'aillent pas grossir celles de lavare Ocan.
tgt_text.945: Moi, je me confie  une simple barque, et  travers les flots tumultueux, Pollux et les vents me poussent au rivage.
tgt_text.947: Jai achev un mouvement plus durable que le bronze, plus lev que les royales pyramides :
tgt_text.948: rien ne saurait le dtruire, ni la pluie qui ronge, ni le fougueux Aquilon, ni linnombrable srie des annes, ni la fuite des temps.
tgt_text.949: Je ne mourrai pas tout entier, et la meilleure partie de moimme vitera la Parque.

tgt_text.4649: La flte, autrefois, n'tait pas comme aujourd'hui toute brillante d'orichalque incrust, et rivale de la trompette :

tgt_text.4651: Depuis, quand ce peuple vint  s'tendre par la victoire, quand un mur plus vaste embrassa la ville, et que le vin ne cessa de couler les jours de fte en lhonneur du dieu de la joie et des folies, alors passa dans les vers et dans le chant cette licence nouvelle des esprits.

tgt_text.4659: Toutefois, ayez soin que vos satyres malins et railleurs ne se prsentent  nous que de la bonne faon, et que le drame tourne dcemment  la plaisanterie.
tgt_text.4660: Si c'est un dieu, si c'est un hros que vous venez de nous montrer tout brillant dor et revtu de la pourpre des rois, gardez qu'il ne tombe de si haut dans l'ignoble langage des tavernes, ou que, de peur de ramper, il n'aille se perdre dans les nues.
tgt_text.4661: La tragdie na pas le temps de samuser anx vers plaisants :

tgt_text.4663: Pour moi, chers Pisons, je n'aurais pas, dans un drame satirique, une manire de style brut et d'expressions courantes;

tgt_text.6916: Le premier chtiment du coupable, c'est qu'il ne peut s'absoudre  son propre tribunal, dt la faveur d'un prteur corrompu le faire sortir vainqueur de l'urne mensongre1 .
tgt_text.6917: De quel il penses-tu, Calvinus, que chacun voit le crime et la perfidie dont tu viens dtre victime?
tgt_text.6918: Ton revenu pourtant nest pas si born que le fardeau d'une perte lgre te doive accabler;

tgt_text.6922: la douleur dun homme ne doit pas tre excessive, ni plus profonde que sa blessure.
tgt_text.6923: Et toi, pour essuyer des maux aussi lgers,  peine peux-tu en supporter la moindre, la plus mince parcelle;

tgt_text.6938: Ainsi vivaient jadis les premiers habitants du Latium, avant que Saturne, dposant le diadme, ne prt, fugitif, la faux du moissonneur;

tgt_text.6953: Maintenant, qu'un ami ne nie point un dpt, qu'il rende un vieux sac avec sa rouille intacte, c'est un prodige de bonne foi :

tgt_text.6955: Si je rencontre un homme d'honneur, intgre, ce miracle, j'en suis aussi surpris que si je voyais la tte d'un quadrupde sur un enfant, des poissons dterrs par le soc de la charrue tonne, ou une mule fconde;

tgt_text.6957: Que diras-tu, si un autre en a perdu deux cent mille, remis pareillement en dpt;

tgt_text.6999: Personne ne joue en pareil cas le dsespoir, et ne se contente darracher les bords de sa robe, de fatiguer ses yeux pour en extraire quelques larmes contraintes :

tgt_text.7002: Est-ce donc que tu es le fils de la poule blanche, et nous de vils poussins clos dufs malheureux?Tu endures une perte lgre, peu faite pour tmouvoir la bile, et tu le vois bien, si tu jettes les yeux sur de plus grands revers.

tgt_text.7008: Ce nest l que la moindre portion des crimes dont le prfet Gallicus entend chaque jour, du lever de laurore au coucher du soleil, le rcit.

tgt_text.7014: Quand,  laspect des oiseaux de Thrace et de leur nue bruyante, le Pygme court au combat, revtu de ses petites armes;

tgt_text.7021: Mais la vengeance est un bien qui me sourit plus que la vie.
tgt_text.7022: Ainsi parle un brutal qui, sans motif le plus souvent ou pour quelque cause lgre, devient furieux, et dont la rage na besoin que de prtexte.
tgt_text.7023: Ce n'est point l le langage de Chrysippe, ni de l'indulgent Thals, ni du vieillard voisin du doux Hymette1 , qui n'et pas voulu, dans son affreuse prison, partager la cigu avec son accusateur.
tgt_text.7024: Lheureus(??) sagesse nous affranchit insensiblement de nos vices sans nombre, nous dpouille de toutes nos erreurs :

tgt_text.7026: En effet, la vengeance toujours est le plaisir dune me troite et faible :
tgt_text.7027: ce qui le prouve, c'est que nul ne savoure plus ce plaisir qu'une femme.
tgt_text.7028: Mais pourquoi te figurer quils chappent au supplice ceux que le cri dchirant dune conscience coupable tient sans cesse en moi, que le remords frappe sourdement de son fouet vengeur, bourreau secret qui torture leur me?
tgt_text.7029: Va, cest un cruel supplice, plus terrible mille fois que tous les tourments invents par Cdicius et Rhadamanthe, que de porter nuit et jour dans son me le tmoin de ses forfaits.
tgt_text.7030: Ce doute ne restera point impuni,  rpondit un jour la Pythie  un Spartiate qui hsitait sil devait retenir un dpt et se lapproprier par un parjure :

tgt_text.7037: En proie  de continuelles angoisses, qui le poursuivent jusqu table, on dirait la fivre qui dessche son gosier;

tgt_text.7042: La nuit, si par hasard ses remords lui laissent un moment de sommeil, si ses membres, longtemps agits sur sa couche, ont enfin trouv le repos, soudain lui apparat le temple avec les autels du dieu qu'il outragea;
tgt_text.7043: et, ce qui glace surtout sa pense, il te voit toi-mme en songe :

tgt_text.7045: Voil ceux qui plissent  chaque clair prcurseur du tonnerre, qui tremblent perdus au moindre murmure des airs!

tgt_text.7066: L'EXEMPLE.Il est bien des vices, Fuscinus, des vices dshonorants, capables de fltrir  jamais le plus heureux naturel, que les pres eux-mmes enseignent et transmettent  leurs enfants.

tgt_text.7069: Non, jamais il ne donnera de meilleures esprances, le jeune homme qui sait apprter la truffe, assaisonner le champignon, et plonger le becfigue flottant dans le mme jus, instruit qu'il fut dans cet art par un dissipateur  barbe grise, son pre et son matre en gourmandise.

tgt_text.7071: Et il enseigne la douceur, l'indulgence qui excuse une faute lgre;

tgt_text.7075: Quels conseils donne-t-il  un jeune homme, lui qui sapplaudit du grincement des chanes, qui s'extasie devant l'inscription dun bagne, d'un cachot rserv  lesclave des champs?
tgt_text.7076: Tu veux que la fille de Larga ne soit pas adultre, elle qui ne pourra jamais numrer les amants de sa mre, les numrer mme avec la plus rapide volubilit, sans reprendre trente fois haleine?

tgt_text.7080: Plus efficaces, plus prompts  nous corrompre, sont les mauvais exemples domestiques, alors qu'ils pntrent l'me avec l'ascendant d'imposantes autorits.

tgt_text.7083: Abstiens-toi donc de toute action condamnable, ne ft-ce ( quel puissant motif! ) que pour prserver de la contagion ceux qui nous doivent la vie;

tgt_text.7091: Car si jamais il mritait la colre du censeur, quil ft ton fils par ses murs, comme il l'est par la ressemblance de sa figure et de son corps, si, plus dprav que toi-mme, il s'garait sur tes pas, tu svirais sans doute, tu le gourmanderais, tu songerais  le dshriter.
tgt_text.7092: Eh! de quel front viens-tu tonner avec la libert dun pre, vieillard plus coupable que cet adolescent, dont la tte, vide de cervelle, rclame depuis longtemps loffice des ventouses?

tgt_text.7098: Eh quoi! misrable, tu t'agites dans la crainte que ton vestibule sali par l'ordure d'un chien n'offusque,  son arrive, les yeux d'un ami, que ton portique ne se montre souill de boue?
tgt_text.7099: et cependant avec une seule demi-mesure de poussire, un seul petit esclave va tout rparer;

tgt_text.7101: Certes, la patrie te doit beaucoup alors que tu lui donnes, que tu donnes au peuple un nouveau citoyen, pourvu toutefois que tu le rendes utile  la patrie, utile  son sol, utile dans la guerre comme dans la paix,

tgt_text.7103: La cigogne nourrit ses petits de serpents et de lzards trouvs loin des routes frayes;

tgt_text.7105: Le vautour qui vient de se repatre de carcasses de chevaux, de chiens et de cadavres suspendus au gibet, revole vers sa couve, et lui apporte des lambeaux sanglants :
tgt_text.7106: tels seront encore les aliments du jeune vautour ds qu'il sera assez fort pour se nourrir lui-mme, pour btir  part son nid sur le sommet des arbres.
tgt_text.7107: Le noble oiseau, ministre de Jupiter, chasse dans les forts le livre et le chevreuil;

tgt_text.7109: bientt, lorsque la race gnreuse prend son essor, aux premiers aiguillons de la faim, elle fond sur cette mme proie qu'elle a savoure au sortir de la coque.
tgt_text.7110: Ctronius avait la manie de btir;

tgt_text.7114: Pendant que Ctronius tale ce faste, il diminue son patrimoine, il dlabre sa fortune :

tgt_text.7116: Cet hritage tout entier, son fils insens le dissipe, btissant de nouvelles campagnes avec des matriaux plus prcieux.Le fils d'un superstitieux observateur du sabbat n'adore que la puissance des nuages et du ciel;
tgt_text.7117: il ne fait aucune diffrence entre la chair humaine et celle du porc, dont s'est abstenu son pre, et bientt il se fait circoncire.
tgt_text.7118: lev dans le mpris des lois romaines, il n'tudie, il ne pratique, il ne rvre que la loi judaque, et tout ce que Mose transmet  ses adeptes dans son livre mystrieux.
tgt_text.7119: Il n'a garde de montrer la route au voyageur qui n'est point de sa secte;
tgt_text.7120: il n'indique une fontaine qu'au seul circoncis.
tgt_text.7121: Et tout cela, parce que son pre passa dans l'inaotion le septime jour de chaque semaine, sans prendre aucune part aux devoirs de la vie.
tgt_text.7122: Si toutefois les jeunes gens se plient volontiers aux mauvais exemples, ils ne suivent quavec contrainte les conseils de l'avarice, sduits quils sont par les dehors d'un vice qui soffre sous l'apparence de la vertu, avec un air, un maintien srieux et une mise austre.
tgt_text.7123: On sait d'ailleurs que lavare reoit les loges donns  l'homme frugal,  l'conome :

tgt_text.7125: Ajoutez que l'homme dont je parle, Je peuple le rvre, merveill de de son industrieux talent :
tgt_text.7126: une fortune sous la main de pareils ouvriers va toujours croissant!
tgt_text.7127: Oui, mais elle saccrot par tous les moyens;

tgt_text.7129: Un pre donc qui se persuade que lavare a le cur pleinement satisfait, qui est lui-mme adorateur de la fortune, et croit que la pauvret heureuse est sans exemple, exhorte ses enfants  suivre la mme route,  s'attacher aux mmes principes.
tgt_text.7130: Le vice a aussi ses prceptes :

tgt_text.7133: Voyez-le, fraudant sur la mesure, chtier les estomacs de ses esclaves :

tgt_text.7135: Il rserve, au milieu de septembre, les restes du hachis de la veille;

tgt_text.7150: Tu ne saurais dire combien de gens ont eu  gmir de pareils outrages, et combien cette tyrannie en a forc de vendre leurs champs.
tgt_text.7154: dit-il, jaime mieux une cosse de lupin, que si tout le voisinage me comblait de ses loges, rduit que je fusse  scier quelques pis sur un petit coin de terre.
tgt_text.7155: Sans doute, tu seras dsormais affranchi de toute maladie, de toute infirmit :

tgt_text.7158: Alors, le vtran qui avait blanchi dans les guerres Puniques, qui avait affront le farouche Pyrrhus et les glaives des Molosses, recevait au terme de sa longue carrire  peine deux arpents de terre, pour prix de ses nombreuses blessures.
tgt_text.7159: Ctait la rcompense des fatigues et du sang vers dans les combats.
tgt_text.7160: Nul ne la trouva jamais au-dessous de son mrite, nul ne taxa la patrie d'ingratitude ou de mauvaise foi.
tgt_text.7161: Cet humble coin de terre nourrissait abondamment le pre lui-mme avec sa famille, dans sa populeuse chaumire, o reposait son pouse enceinte, o foltraient quatre jeunes enfants, lun n dune esclave, les trois autres hritiers du matre.
tgt_text.7162: Aprs le repas ordinaire, un repas plus frugal attendait les ans au retour de la vigne ou des champs :

tgt_text.7164: De nos jours, ces deux arpents ne suffisent pas  nos jardins.

tgt_text.7168: Eh! quel respect des lois, quelle crainte, quel scrupule arrte jamais limpatience de lavare?Vivez contents de vos cabanes et de ces coteaux,  mes enfants, disait jadis le Marse, lHernique et le vieillard du Ves tin1 .
tgt_text.7169: Demandons  la charrue le pain qui suffit  nos tables.
tgt_text.7170: Ainsi nous serons agrables aux divinits champtres, dont lappui secourable, aprs le bienfait dune moisson dlicieuse, a permis que lhomme se dgott du gland qui nourrissait ses pres.
tgt_text.7171: Jamais il ne se souillera daucun crime, celui qui ne rougit pas de chausser la gutre rustique pour affronter la glace, qui brave les Aquilons avec des peaux retournes.
tgt_text.7172: Cest la pourpre trangre, inconnue  nos climats, qui conduit  tous les crimes.Voil quels prceptes nos aeux donnaient  leurs enfants.
tgt_text.7173: Aujourdhui, aprs lautomne, un pre court, au milieu de la nuit, rveiller  grands cris son fils qui repose :

tgt_text.7207: Ainsi, l'incendie dont tu allumas la premire tincelle, tu le verras stendre au loin, et tout dvorer sur son passage.

tgt_text.7231: Et ce beau dvouement, c'est afin de pouvoir revenir, la bourse pleine, tout fier dtaler des sacs gonfls d'or, d'avoir vu les monstres de l'Ocan et ses dieux marins!Chaque mortel a sa manie :

tgt_text.7282: Entre deux villes voisines, Coptos et Tentyra, rgne encore une ardente inimiti, une haine immortelle, plaie profonde que rien ne saurait gurir.

tgt_text.0: INTRODUCTION TO THE ODES, .... xvilTHE ODES, IINTRODUCTION TO THE CARMEN SECULARE AND THE ERODES, J I ,I 91THE CARMEN SECULARE, c 94THE EPODES, I 96INTRODUCTION TO THE SATIRES, 115THE SATIRES, 121INTRODUCTION TO THE EPISTLES, I 205THE EPISTLES, 209THE ART OF POETRY, , , 276No ancient author has given in his writings more facts than Horace has done, from which a biographer can construct the story of his life.
tgt_text.1: These notices are introduced incidentally and in no ostentatious manner.
tgt_text.2: They come in quite natur ally, and without offence to good taste.
tgt_text.3: From them we learn that Horace's father was a libertinus, or freed slave, a member of the Horatia tribus in Apulia, as is supposed-hence the name.
tgt_text.4: The future poet was born in 65 B.C. at Venusia, now Venosa, in Apulia, on the confines of Lucania, and so he says of himself " Lucanus an Appulus anceps."
tgt_text.5: Why he was called Flaccus is not known.
tgt_text.6: As his father gained his freedom before the boy's birth, young Horace was an ingenuus, or freeborn Roman citizen.
tgt_text.7: His father was a coactor, that is, either a collector of taxes for the state, or one who took the payments at auction sales.
tgt_text.8: Whatever his occupation may have been, he seems to have early laid past a little money, which enabled him to buy a small property at Venusia, and to give his son the education of a Roman gentleman.
tgt_text.10: We know nothing of his mother individually.
tgt_text.11: She had probably died when he was very young.
tgt_text.12: At all events he makes no reference to her, except as one of his parents, with whom he was quite content, and whom he would not have changed for greater and richer ones if he had had the choice.
tgt_text.14: She may have been to him the type of that Apulian woman whom he praises in Epode ii.
tgt_text.15: 39, sqq.Horace's early education was conducted at Rome under Orbilius Pupillus of "thrashing notoriety," with whom he studied grammar and some of the old Latin authors.
tgt_text.16: He also read Homer with the same master, and acquired with various teachers some of the modern accomplishments" of those days, such as music and rhetoric.
tgt_text.17: But Horace's father was not content that his son should finish his education under Orbilius.
tgt_text.18: Athens was in those days the University of the world, and to Athens accord ingly the lad was sent, when he was about twenty years of age, to study philosophy and literature, and to improve himself in Greek.
tgt_text.19: There he met many young men belonging to the best families in Rome, pursuing their higher education as he was, and with some of them he formed a lifelong friendship.
tgt_text.20: There, also, the tenor of his life was suddenly changed by the events that followed on the assassination of Julius Csar.
tgt_text.21: Brutus and Cassius called at Athens on their way to the Eastern Provinces which had been assigned them, and while Cassius went on to Syria, Brutus loitered for a time in the city ostensibly to hear the lectures of some of the philosophers, but really, it would seem, to enlist on the re publican side as many as possible of the " young bloods" of Rome then "in residence."
tgt_text.22: It was here that Horace received his appointment as Military Tribune, for which he was by no means fit.
tgt_text.23: But his soldier life was of short duration.
tgt_text.24: The battle of Philippi took place in 42 B.C., and there he was obliged to run for his life, like others, and leave his shield behind, as he tells us in apparent soberness, though it may be a mere joke against himself.
tgt_text.25: He is the only authority for the occurrence of the un soldierly act.
tgt_text.26: Before he was called off with Brutus to the war he is said to have visited many parts of Greece, to which he has made some passing references in his writings.
tgt_text.27: When Brutus and Cassius were defeated by Octavianus and Antony, and the Republican party were thoroughly discredited, and the men of law and order came into power, an amnesty was proclaimed, and under its kindly leave Horace among many others returned to Rome.
tgt_text.28: But he came back penniless and fatherless, as his property at Venusia had been confiscated, and his good old father had passed away, probably during his absence.
tgt_text.29: But curiously enough he does not refer to the sad event, as we should have expected.
tgt_text.30: For some time after his return to Rome he seems to have supported himself by " writing, for the booksellers," pieces of a satirical kind which made him many enemies.
tgt_text.31: But ere long he gained the post of Scribe or Qustor's clerk, either by purchase or by the interest of friends.
tgt_text.32: Greater prosperity, however, was in store for him.
tgt_text.33: He was intro duced to Maecenas by Virgil and Varius, probably about 40 B.C.1
tgt_text.34: It was nine months, he tells us, before Maecenas invited him to his house, but when he once became a guest, he made his way to the heart of the Minister almost imme diately, and from that time forth the friends were all in all to each other till death separated them.
tgt_text.35: During the next year after this he formed one of the party which made the famous "Journey to Brundusium," the events of which are duly recorded in Sat., I. v.Horace had a house in Rome, and a moderate 11 establish ment " in which he could receive friends, even Maecenas, with suitable appointments.
tgt_text.36: But he much preferred a country life, and so spent a large part of the year away from the city.
tgt_text.37: To this change of residence we owe his beautiful and touching descriptions of scenery, and of honest country people and their simple ways (Epode ii., &c.).
tgt_text.38: On the other hand, he takes no pains to conceal his dislike of the din and bustle of mighty Rome, and of the vice and frivolity of life in the city as compared with the purity of morals and staidness of character of the peasantry (Ode iii. 6).
tgt_text.39: The passages in which he treats of the worries of town life and the joys of the country are among the most charming in his writings.
tgt_text.40: It was about 33 or 32 B.C. that Maecenas gave Horace a present of the small Sabine estate, or farm, to which he so often makes reference.
tgt_text.41: It lay mostly in the valley of Ustica, about 30 miles from Rome, 12 from Tibur, and 4 from Varia, the nearest small town or village.
tgt_text.42: Its quiet seclusion had a great attraction for the poet, whom it always if set up " again when wearied with society in Rome, and with all the turmoils and interruptions of the busy town.
tgt_text.43: There he seems to have spent the happiest days of his life.
tgt_text.45: On the farm he had a steward, eight slaves, and five resident families.
tgt_text.46: His style of living both in Rome and at his Sabine farm was simple, frugal, and temperate.
tgt_text.47: In the country he employed his time in reading, writing, strolling about and enjoying the hills, the streams, the woods, and doing a little on his farm or in his garden.
tgt_text.48: He revels in the pleasures of the place, and speaks with deep affection of the fountain of Bandusia, the stream Digentia, the rocks, the glens, the lowing oxen, and the browsing goats.
tgt_text.49: He was a lover of nature in all her aspects, and he had a kindly heart for man and for beast.
tgt_text.50: Praeneste, Tibur, and Bai were favourite places with him for a temporary residence.
tgt_text.51: See his own description of his life in the city in Sat., I. vi. 112, sqq.
tgt_text.52: In one of his touching Odes (Bk. II. xvii.) he declares that when Maecenas dies he will not remain behind they will take the last journey together;
tgt_text.53: and so it came to pass that Horace died only a few weeks after his faithful friend and patron, to whom he delighted to address ode after ode.
tgt_text.54: They were buried near one another on the Esquiline Hill.
tgt_text.55: Maecenas introduced Horace to Augustus, and with him also the poet became a favourite.
tgt_text.56: It was at the request of the Emperor that Horace composed the Carmen Saeculare for the celebration of the games of 17 B.C.
tgt_text.57: Of this duty he was,, no doubt, justly proud.
tgt_text.58: Augustus wished him to become his private secretary, but he declined on the ground of health.
tgt_text.59: In person he was small of size, and in advancing years rather stout.
tgt_text.60: In youth his hair was black, but he became early grey:
tgt_text.61: his eyes were weak and liable to inflammation.
tgt_text.62: As a young man he was attentive to his appearance, Quern tenues decuere tog nitidique capilli, but grew rather careless as life advanced.
tgt_text.63: His temper, by his own account, was hasty, but he was easily appeased.
tgt_text.64: He had his faults and failings, but even these still leaned to virtue's side.
tgt_text.65: In some of the Odes he seems to represent himself as a libertine, but these are thought to be mere imitations of his Greek models, and not applicable to his own life.
tgt_text.67: Horace does not pose as a man superior to his neigh bours, though he says 11 Odi profanum vulgus," in a special application :
tgt_text.68: nor does he bore us with his own affairs, but gives us only so much that we should like to hear more.
tgt_text.69: He often refers to his humble origin, and also to his being the friend of the rich and great, but never in such a way as that we should be inclined to dub him either a " bully of humility," on the one hand, or a tuft-hunter and a snob, on the other.
tgt_text.70: He is a plain, unsophisticated, sensible man, who gains our confidence by the simple, quiet way in which he refers to himself, his life, and his friends.
tgt_text.71: The two or three occasions on which he speaks of him self somewhat egotistically, as in Ode xx.
tgt_text.72: Book II., and Ode xxx. Book III., do not outweigh the general and consistent character which he maintains for modest humility.
tgt_text.73: The former Ode seems to have been a mock heroic reply to an invitation from Maecenas;
tgt_text.74: and the latter a humorous imitation of similar self-laudations by Sappho and Ennius.
tgt_text.75: It has been stated in the Life of Horace that after his schoolboy days were over he went to Athens to pursue higher studies in philosophy, and to cultivate a more thorough knowledge of Greek Literature.
tgt_text.76: In following out the latter object, he seems to have read much of that Lyric poetry of which Alcus and Sappho were leading repre sentatives, and which, it would appear, had a special charm for him.
tgt_text.77: This, as it turned out, gained him his lasting fame.
tgt_text.78: When the desire took hold of him to adapt the strains of Italy to the olian Muse we know not, as he has not told us;
tgt_text.79: but it would seem that he had written much after his return to Rome before he began to transfer the metres and subjects of the Greek Lyricists into Latin Odes.
tgt_text.80: The improvement in his style of writing, which arose from his great practice in satiric composition, induced him, it is said, to put forth all his powers in Lyric poetry, as suiting his taste, and as being a novelty in Rome.
tgt_text.81: This he did for seven years.
tgt_text.82: In the first six he sent forth the first three books of the Odes.
tgt_text.84: These Odes, being the product of his riper years, are generally considered to be the most perfect and most polished of his writings, in the matter of form at least.
tgt_text.85: They give proof of maturity of mind and judgment, of a keen insight into life and its important conditions and relationships, rather than of poetic inspiration of the highest type, or of exuberant imagination.
tgt_text.86: In the Odes the language is generally polished, the thoughts lucid in conception, the diction terse, and the metres remarkable for beauty and harmony.
tgt_text.87: But occasion ally we meet with phrases and sentences of a prosaic kind, and with extravagances inconsistent with Horace's usual good taste.
tgt_text.88: When Horace speaks from the heart and with his natural fire, as he does in Odes of a national and patriotic kind, such as the second of the First Book, he rises to real beauty and even to grandeur;
tgt_text.89: but if his subject has been proposed to him, and he is expected to write " to order," the result is very different:
tgt_text.90: and naturally so, as common sense and experience will readily admit it must be.
tgt_text.91: Horace's first attempts would necessarily be translations, or at least mere imitations, of his Greek models.
tgt_text.92: Others are independent compositions in Greek fashion, and others again original subjects from the public life of Rome and Italy, or on the private affairs of his friends.
tgt_text.93: The Odes may be classified as follows:
tgt_text.97: There are many others of a miscellaneous kind, dealing with the beauties of the country;
tgt_text.98: with virtues, personal and social, with old Roman character and heroism, and with ancient legends of gods and men.
tgt_text.99: It is in the first of these that Horace appears to most advantage.
tgt_text.100: In them he breathes forth in words of fire his ardent love of fatherland and home;
tgt_text.101: he proclaims with honest pride the past glories of the state;
tgt_text.102: and with un bounded admiration he recalls the uprightness and the honesty of the good old days.
tgt_text.103: On the other hand, he deprecates in sad and warning tones the defection from ancient standards which he sees is taking place, the decay in morals and in military spirit, and the deterioration of his fellow-citizens in all those qualities which went in olden times to form a Roman of the highest type.

tgt_text.525: and how the river of the Medes, just added to the conquered tribes, rolls onward with its lessening waves;
tgt_text.526: how the Geloni, in their narrowed plains, range only in the bounds we set.
tgt_text.527: Licinius, more safely shall you guide your life by neither pressing out to sea, nor always hugging close, in dread of storm, the dangerous shore.
tgt_text.528: The man who loves the golden mean escapes2 the squalor of a crazy hut, and wisely shuns a courtly hall which nought but envy brings.
tgt_text.529: Oftenest is the tallest pine tossed by the winds, and lofty towers fall with a heavier crash, and lightning smites the highest peaks.
tgt_text.530: A mind well-balanced hopes in adversity for better times, and in prosperity it fears reverse.
tgt_text.531: 'Tis Jove who hideous winters brings again;
tgt_text.533: If we fare ill to-day, it will not always be so:
tgt_text.534: sometimes Apollo with his lyre wakes up the silent Muse, nor does he always bend his bow.
tgt_text.535: Approve yourself in straits a man of spirit and of pluck :
tgt_text.536: and wisely too take in your bulging sails, filled by too fair a breeze.
tgt_text.537: What warlike Spaniard plots, what the Scythian with Hadria's flood to keep him back, intends, stay not Hirpinus to inquire, nor worry for the wants of life that little needs.
tgt_text.538: Sleek youth and beauty fly away, while sapless age expels our sportive loves and ready sleep.
tgt_text.539: The vernal flowers present not always equal hues, nor does the moon for ever shine with blushing face :
tgt_text.540: Why do you strain your mind which cannot grasp the counsels of eternity ?
tgt_text.541: Why don't we rather, while we can, lying at random thus beneath some lofty plane or fir, indulge in wine, our whitening locks with roses fragrant and with Syrian perfumes wet ?
tgt_text.543: What slave will quickly cool the cups of strong Falernian in the passing stream?
tgt_text.544: Who to our retreat will coax the wanton Lyde ?
tgt_text.545: Come, bid her hasten with her ivory lyre :
tgt_text.546: and bind her hair like Spartan maid in plain and simple knot.
tgt_text.547: Seek not, I pray, that to my harp's soft strains I should adapt the wars of fierce Numantia, or of stubborn Hannibal, or the Sicilian main, purple with Punic blood;
tgt_text.548: or savage Lapith, Hylus over-charged with wine, or those subdued by mighty arm of Hercules, Earth's giant sons, whose dangerous charge caused Saturn's glittering halls to tremble to their base :
tgt_text.549: but you, Mcenas, will tell in prose great Csar's wars, and better will describe how necks of threatening kings were led in triumph through the streets of Rome.
tgt_text.550: The Muse has willed that I should celebrate Licymnia's sweet songs, your mistress dear, her brightly sparkling eyes, and faithful heart with true and mutual love, who condescends to bear her foot with grace into the dance, and on Diana's day to join in sportive mirth, and playfully encircle with her arms the maidens in their holiday attire.
tgt_text.551: One lock of fair Licymnia's hair you would not change, I ween, for all that rich Achaemenes possessed, or Mygdon's fabled wealth in fertile Phrygia, or Arab homes with treasure stored;
tgt_text.552: while to your kisses warm she turns her neck, or with coy cruelty declines :
tgt_text.553: who is more pleased that they be ta'en than even he who claims them, and who at times is first to snatch them quickly ?
tgt_text.554: 'Twas an unlucky day he planted you, whoever did it first, and 'twas with unholy hands he reared you up to be the ruin of posterity, and to disgrace the countryside.
tgt_text.555: That man, I verily believe, would readily have broke his fathers neck, and smeared with blood of guests his holy shrines:
tgt_text.556: he dealt with Colchian poisons and with every crime which villany conceives, who set you up, and in my very garden too, ill-omened trunk, to fall upon your masters un offending head.
tgt_text.557: Man never is forewarned enough from hour to hour what danger he should shun.
tgt_text.558: The Punic sailor dreads the Bosphorus, and fears not sudden fate from other source:
tgt_text.559: the soldier dreads the Parthian's arrow and his rapid flight:
tgt_text.560: the Parthian, a Roman prison and its iron chains;
tgt_text.561: but some unthought of stroke of death has swept away the tribes of men and still will sweep away.
tgt_text.562: How nearly did I see the realms of swarthy Proserpine, and acus in judgment seated, and the abodes for good men set apart, and Sappho wailing on olian lyre the cold ness of her country's maids, and you, Alcaeus, sounding more loudly with your golden quill the hardships of the sea, the grievous ills of exile, the woeful deeds of war:
tgt_text.563: the Shades admire them while they sing of things which claim a sacred silence;
tgt_text.564: but with greater eagerness the mob in serried crowds drink in with greedy ear the tales of battles and of banished kings.
tgt_text.565: What wonder, when that monster of the hundred heads, dazed by their songs, hangs down his sable ears;
tgt_text.566: and snakes entwined in Furies' locks are lulled to rest.
tgt_text.567: Aye, e'en Prometheus, and Pelops' father too, are from their ills beguiled by the sweet sounds :
tgt_text.568: nor longer does Orion care to chase the lion and the timid lynx.
tgt_text.571: dear Postumus, the fleeting years are speed ing quickly by, and piety itself shall bring no stay to wrinkles and advancing age and Death whom none can foil:
tgt_text.572: not though, my friend, with countless bulls for every passing day you would appease relentless Pluto, who confines the monster Geryon of triple shape and size, and Tityos, with his dismal stream-a stream that must be crossed by all who on Earth's bounties feed, whether we be rich and great, or poor and needy hinds.
tgt_text.573: 'Twill be in vain to shun the bloody fight, and broken billows of hoarse Hadria's shores, and vain to guard against the south wind, baleful to men in autumn time.
tgt_text.574: The black Cocytus we are doomed to see as in sluggish stream he winds along, and Danaus' race of evil name, and Sisyphus, own son of olus, to ceaseless toil condemned.
tgt_text.575: Earth must be left, and home and winsome wife;
tgt_text.576: and of the trees you fondly tend not one shall follow to the tomb its short-lived lord, except the hated cypress.
tgt_text.577: An heir more worthy than yourself shall quaff your cask of Ccuban, by hundred keys secured, and stain the polished floor with lordly wine which shames the Pontiffs' feasts.
tgt_text.578: Soon princely halls shall leave few acres for the plough:
tgt_text.579: on every side great fish-ponds shall be seen more spacious than the Lucrine lake, and the unwedded plane shall oust the elm :
tgt_text.580: then beds of violets and myrtle groves, and every flower of sweeter scent, shall spread their fragrance over olive grounds which yielded profit to their former lord:
tgt_text.581: then shall the matted branches of the bay ward off the burning sunbeams.
tgt_text.582: It was not thus laid down in days of Romulus and frugal1 Cato, and in our fathers' simple ways.
tgt_text.583: Their private income was but scant, the public revenue was great:
tgt_text.584: no porticoes by private standard ruled, ten feet in length, received the cooling northern shade, nor did the law permit that they should spurn the cottage built of chance cut turf, bidding them to deck their towns by public funds, and with fresh-hewn stones to build them noble temples for their gods.
tgt_text.585: The man who in a storm is caught in the gean main implores the gods for rest, soon as the scowling cloud has hid the moon from view, and when the stars shine with a fitful light to those upon the sea.
tgt_text.586: Thrace, furious in war, implores repose ;
tgt_text.587: the Medes, with gorgeous quiver, Grosphus, seek repose, which diamonds cannot buy, nor gold nor purple robes.
tgt_text.588: For neither hoarded wealth nor Consul's henchman can remove the racking tumults of the mind, and vexing cares that flit around e'en panelled roofs.
tgt_text.589: That man lives happily on frugal means, upon whose modest board there shines the salt bowl which his fathers used, and whom nor fear nor niggard greed deprives of peaceful sleep.
tgt_text.590: Why aim we, short-lived men, at many things with eager zeal?
tgt_text.591: Why seek we lands warmed by another sun ?
tgt_text.592: What man that flies his father land can from himself escape ?
tgt_text.593: Morbid cares ascend the brass-prowed galleys, nor do they leave the troops of horse, swifter than stags or than the eastern breeze that drives the clouds away.
tgt_text.594: Let not the mind with present lot content be anxious for things beyond, but mitigate life's crosses with a placid smile :
tgt_text.595: there's nothing happy on its every side.
tgt_text.596: An early death bore hence the famed Achilles in his prime;
tgt_text.597: age, protracted long, wasted Tithonus' powers, and time perchance will grant to me some favour he denies to you.
tgt_text.598: Round you there bleat an hundred flocks of sheep, and cows in Sicily their welcome low :
tgt_text.599: to you the harnessed steeds their greetings neigh :
tgt_text.600: you wool twice dipped in Afric dye with choicest garments clothes :
tgt_text.601: to me did Fate, who never errs, assign a tiny farm and subtle vein of Grecian song, and courage to despise the envious crowd.
tgt_text.602: Why take my life away by your complaints :
tgt_text.603: It is not Heaven's will nor mine, Mcenas, that you should die before me, great glory of my life and prop of all my weal.
tgt_text.605: if some untimely stroke should take you hence, a portion of my very soul, why should the other stay behind, to me not half so dear, and but in part alive ?
tgt_text.606: That fatal day shall ruin bring to both.
tgt_text.607: 'Tis not a hollow oath I swear:
tgt_text.608: we'll go, we'll go, whenever you lead on, prepared to take that latest journey side by side.
tgt_text.609: Nor fiery Chimra's breath, nor Gyas with his hundred hands, were he to rise again, shall tear me from you :
tgt_text.610: so 'tis decreed by mighty Justice and the sister Fates.
tgt_text.611: Whether 'tis Libra or the dreaded Scorpion, my natal hour's more stormy part, that rules my fate, or Capricornus lording it o'er Western seas, our horoscopes agree with strange accord.
tgt_text.612: Jove's counteracting light saved you from Saturn's baleful glare, and slowed the speed of Fate's swift wings when in the crowded theatre the people raised three times the shout of joy:
tgt_text.613: a tree-stem falling on my head had surely been my death, had not good Faunus eased the blow with present help-that kindly guardian of the merchant guild.
tgt_text.615: The promised sacrifice forget not, and the shrine you vowed :
tgt_text.616: for my part, I will slay a lowly lamb.
tgt_text.617: Nor ivory couch 2 nor gilded roof shows bright in my abode, nor do Hymettus' slabs on columns rest, hewn from the rocks of distant Africa, nor have I, as an unknown heir, dwelt in the halls of Attalus, nor do noble matrons spin for me Laconian purple:
tgt_text.618: but honesty I have, and generous vein of poet's wit, and poor as I am the rich man pays me court:
tgt_text.619: I weary not the gods for more, nor from my friend in power do I a greater boon demand,my single Sabine farm contents me quite.
tgt_text.620: Day treads on heels of day, and infant moons make haste to wane.
tgt_text.621: You, on the very brink of death, contract for hewing marble blocks, and never thinking of your grave you houses build, and hasten to remove still farther back the margin of the sea that breaks on Bai's coast with noisy surge, not rich enough with main- land shore.
tgt_text.622: What means it that you forcibly remove the landmarks which your neighbour set, and in your greed o'erleap your client's fence ?
tgt_text.623: Husband and wife are turned adrift, bearing in their arms their squalid sons and fathers' gods.
tgt_text.624: And yet no hall more certainly awaits its wealthy lord than the " appointed House" of Orcus greedy as himself.
tgt_text.626: Earth opens with impartial mouth for pauper and for prince;
tgt_text.627: nor did Hell's ferryman for golden lure bear back to upper Earth the great Prometheus with his many wiles.
tgt_text.628: Orcus confines the haughty Tantalus and all his race:
tgt_text.629: he attends, invoked or not, to free the poor man when his task is done.
tgt_text.630: Bacchus have I seen amid sequestered rocks teaching his strains-doubt it not, posterity-and listening nymphs, and pointed ears of Satyrs with the feet of goats.
tgt_text.631: Evoe, my spirit quakes with fear still fresh, and in my bosom full of Bacchus tumults of joy prevail.
tgt_text.632: Evoe, spare me, 0 Liber, spare, feared for thy dreadful thyrsus.
tgt_text.633: 'Tis no impiety to sing untiring Bacchantes, and the springs of wine, and plenteous rills of milk, and again to tell of honey dropping from the hollow stem :
tgt_text.634: 'tis no impiety to celebrate thy blessed spouse's crown placed midst the stars, and Pen theus' palace, by no slight ruin rent, and Thracian Lycurgus' death.
tgt_text.635: Thou turnest streams aside, thou rul'st the Indian sea;
tgt_text.636: mellowed with wine, thou on the lonely heights dost bind the Bacchantes' locks-no harm to them-with twisted vipers:
tgt_text.637: and when the impious giants tried through upper air to scale the palace of thy father Jove, thou Rhtus did'st hurl back with lion's claws, and dreadful jaw;
tgt_text.638: though better fitted, as 'twas said, for dance and mirth, thou wast reputed as nowise equal to the toils of fight;
tgt_text.639: but, all the same, thou wast the arbiter of peace and war.
tgt_text.640: 1 Cerberus, in harmless mood, gazed at thee with thy golden horn equipped, and gently wagged his tail, and with his triple tongue he licked thy feet and legs on thy return.
tgt_text.641: A bard of double form, I shall be borne aloft through liquid air upon no common and no feeble wing, nor longer shall I stay on earth, and soaring above envy's range I shall desert the busy haunts of men.
tgt_text.642: Sprung though I be from humble stock, I, whom thou call'st " dear friend," Maecenas, shall never die, nor shall I be confined by Stygian flood.
tgt_text.643: Now, even now, the roughening skin is settling on my limbs, and in my upper parts I now assume the white bird's form;
tgt_text.644: and downy plumage grows upon my fingers and my back.
tgt_text.645: Now as a bird of tuneful song I shall behold the shores of moan ing Bosphorus and the Gtulian Syrtes and the northern plains, more famed2 than Icarus, that crafty son of Daedalus.
tgt_text.646: Me the Colchian and the Dacian too shall know, who seeks to hide his fear of Marsian bands, and the remote Geloni;
tgt_text.647: me shall the skilled Iberian learn, the German, and the Gaul.
tgt_text.648: Let not a dirge be heard around my empty bier, nor squalid sign of grief, nor useless plaints:
tgt_text.649: the "fare well " cry restrain, and leave undone the needless honours of the tomb.
tgt_text.650: The common herd of men I hate, and hold them far at bay.
tgt_text.652: the Muses' priest, I sing to maidens and to youths strains never heard before.
tgt_text.653: The sway of dreaded kings can only vassals reach:
tgt_text.654: the sway of Jove, by rout of giants famed, is over kings themselves-of Jove who shakes all Nature by a nod.
tgt_text.655: 'Tis true, no doubt, that one o'er wider range in trenches plants the trees which prop his vines:
tgt_text.656: that one of nobler birth in search of office to the Campus hies:
tgt_text.657: another better in morals and repute asserts his claims:
tgt_text.658: a third has clients many more:
tgt_text.659: but stern Necessity, from bias free, allots the fate of high and low :
tgt_text.660: her ample urn shakes every name.
tgt_text.661: For him above whose guilty head there hangs a naked sword, Sicilian dainties will not " force sweet appetite ";
tgt_text.662: nor will the song of birds or strains of harp restore his sleep.
tgt_text.663: Calm slumber scorns not the cottage home of rustic men, nor shady bank, nor Tempe fanned by western breeze.
tgt_text.664: That man who seeks what's just enough-no more-the troubled sea does not disturb, nor fury of Arcturus as he sets, nor of the rising Kids, nor vineyards beaten down by hail, nor farms betray ing hope, when trees now blame the heavy rains, and now the dogstar heat that burns the fields, and now unfriendly winters.
tgt_text.665: The fishes find their sea curtailed by masses to the depths flung down ;
tgt_text.666: here the contractor 1 with his crowd of men, the master, too, with household slaves pour in the rubble, disdaining Nature's bounds.
tgt_text.667: But fear and Con science' threats mount by the ladder which the owner climbs, and gloomy care leaves not the brass-prowed shipaye, even firmly sits behind the Knight.
tgt_text.668: But if nor Phrygian stone nor purple robe brighter than stars, nor strong Falernian wine, nor Persian nard, compose the mind when ill at ease, why should I rear a lofty Hall in modern style, with pillars court ing envy's grudge ?
tgt_text.669: Why should I change my Sabine Vale for splendour with its greater toils ?
tgt_text.670: Let Roman youth, made strong by active war, learn to endure privation in a happy mood;
tgt_text.671: let him as horseman bold with dreaded spear harass the daring Mede, and spend his life in open air, and midst alarms of foes.
tgt_text.672: Let wife and daughter of the warring king, as from the hostile walls they look, heave many a sigh, alas !
tgt_text.673: lest princely spouse, untried in war, provoke the lion, dangerous to stir, whom blood-thirst anger hurries on through thickest of the fight.
tgt_text.674: A pleasant and a noble thing it is to die for father land :
tgt_text.675: Death hunts to doom the man who flies, nor does he spare the trembling knees and back of coward youth.
tgt_text.676: True worth that knows not base defeat, shines with a halo bright, nor does it take or lay aside the axe of Power at changing whim of fickle mobs.
tgt_text.677: Worth, that opens heaven to men who should not die, directs her course by ways from others hid, and on her fleeting pinion spurns the vulgar crowd and damp and foggy Earth.
tgt_text.678: For faithful silence, too, there is a sure reward:
tgt_text.679: the man who would divulge the sacred rites of holy Ceres I should forbid to stay beneath the roof that covers me, or to unmoor with me a fragile bark:
tgt_text.680: often has Jove, by slight enraged, in penalties con joined impure and pure :
tgt_text.681: Vengeance, with her halting foot, has rarely failed to catch the wicked, though he gains the start.
tgt_text.682: Him who defends the Right and is in purpose firm, nor perverse zeal of citizens in passing laws unjust, nor frown of threatening tyrant shakes in his fixed resolve, nor Auster, boisterous ruler of the restless Hadria, nor the mighty hand of Jove with thunder armed:
tgt_text.683: should shattered heaven fall about his ears, the crash will strike him dauntless still.
tgt_text.684: Thus Pollux and the roaming Hercules striving upward reached the starry heights, and in their midst reclining Caesar im bibes the nectar with empurpled mouth.
tgt_text.685: For such deserts O Bacchus, did thy tigers bear thee up, drawing thy car with untrained necks:
tgt_text.686: by means of this did Romulus fly Acheron on steeds of Mars, when Juno spoke what pleased the gods in council seated :
tgt_text.687: Ilium, Ilium,1 a doom-fraught and polluted judge, and paramour from foreign land, have turned to ashes-consigned for punishment to chaste Minerva and to me, with people and with cheating king, ever since that day when false Laomedon deprived the gods of promised hire.
tgt_text.688: No longer now that ill-famed guest decks out his form for Spartan dame, and Priam's perjured house no more retards the onset of the valiant Greeks by Hector's might, and war prolonged by our disputes is over now.
tgt_text.689: Henceforth I will forego my bitter grudge, and will forgive, for sake of Mars, my hated grandson, whom Trojan priestess bore :
tgt_text.690: him will I allow to reach these realms of light, to drink the juice of nectar, and to be enrolled among the peaceful ranks of gods.
tgt_text.691: So long as wide and stormy seas shall roll 'twixt Ilium and Rome let exiled sons of Troy reign prosperous where'er they please:
tgt_text.692: so long as cattle tread on Priam's and on Paris' tomb, and wild beasts there in safety hide their young, let the proud Capitol stand forth in glittering pomp, and let the martial Rome give laws to conquered Medes.
tgt_text.693: Let her, a dreaded power, extend her fame to those far-distant coasts, where the dividing flood parts Europe from the Afric shore, where swollen Nile o'erflows the plains;
tgt_text.694: braver in scorning gold un-mined-so is it better placed when hid in Earth-than in turning it to human needs with sacrilegious hands that nothing sacred spare.
tgt_text.695: Whatever bounds have to the world been set, these shall she reach in arms, eager to see those parts where blazing heat revels unchecked, where clouds prevail, and soaking rains.
tgt_text.696: But to Quirites, famed in war, their fate I tell on these my terms, that in excess of love, and over confident in strength, they seek not to rebuild th' ancestral walls of Troy.
tgt_text.697: Troy's fortunes, born again with evil omen, shall be repeated in disaster bitter as before, I, sister and spouse of Jove heading my conquering bands.
tgt_text.698: Thrice were a wall of brass to rise by Phoebus' aid, thrice should it fall, by Argives levelled to the ground;
tgt_text.699: thrice should the captive wife lament her husband and her children slain.
tgt_text.700: This will not suit the sportive lyre :
tgt_text.702: Cease to relate the gods' discourse with froward will, and bv thy humble strains debase such lofty themes.
tgt_text.703: O Queen Calliope, from heaven come down and on thy pipe pour forth a long and stately strain or, if thou wish it rather, with clear and tuneful voice, or on the strings of Phoebus' lyre.
tgt_text.704: Do you hear it, friends, or does a fond delusion mock my brain ?
tgt_text.705: Methinks I hear her, and I seem to wander through the hallowed groves, where charming waters glide and gentle breezes blow.
tgt_text.706: Me, when a child, worn out by play, and overcome by sleep, the woodland doves of storied fame covered with leaves on Voltur's slope, beyond Apulia's bounds, my early home-a wondrous sight to all who dwell in lofty Acherontia's home, and Bantia's woods and fertile fields of low Forentum !
tgt_text.707: how I could sleep secure from deadly snakes, and grizzly bears, and how my limbs were heaped with sacred bay and myrtle duly culled -a child inspired with strength from Heaven.
tgt_text.708: Your care, O Muses, yours I say, I'm borne to lofty Sabine hills, or, be't my choice, to cold Prneste, or Tibur's slopes, or Bai's sea-washed shore.
tgt_text.709: Me welcome at your foun tains and your choirs, not Philippi's rout, nor cursed tree could kill, nor Palinurus in Sicilian seas.
tgt_text.710: Since you shall be at hand, as sailor shall I brave the raging Bosphorus, and, as a traveller, Assyria's burning sands.
tgt_text.711: With you I'll visit Britain, to the stranger fierce, and the Concanian who delights in horses' blood.
tgt_text.712: With you in safety I shall see the quiver-armed Geloni and the Scythian Don.
tgt_text.713: 'Tis you that in Pierian cave regale exalted Csar eager to complete his toils, so soon as he has placed in towns his war-worn troops.
tgt_text.714: You, deities benign, both peaceful counsels prompt, and joy in those you give.
tgt_text.715: We know how he who rules the sluggish earth and calms the storm-swept sea, and cities too and realms of gloom, and with a righteous sway governs both gods and mortal men, slew with descending bolt the Titans and the giant host.
tgt_text.716: That band of youths of horrid form had caused to Jove great dread, relying on their strength of arm, and the fell brothers too, who sought to place Mount Pelion on Olympus with its shady woods.
tgt_text.717: But what could bold Typhus do, and sturdy Mimas ?
tgt_text.718: or what, Porphyrion in attitude of fight?
tgt_text.719: what could Rhcetus, and Enceladus,a daring spearman with whole trunks up-torn,-avail against the sounding shield of Pallas ?
tgt_text.720: Here Vulcan stood, for battle keen :
tgt_text.721: there mother Juno stayed, and he who never will lay down his bow, Apollo, god of Delos and of Patara, who in Castalia's crystal dew is wont to bathe his flowing locks;
tgt_text.722: who haunts the groves of Lycia and his native woods.
tgt_text.723: Force void of judgment falls by inherent weight:
tgt_text.724: force, duly tempered, the deities advance to greater power:
tgt_text.725: but they detest that strength which all impiety contrives.
tgt_text.726: Gyas of the hundred hands attests my sentiments, and Orion, noted tempter of the chaste Diana, slain by the Virgin's shaft.
tgt_text.727: Earth grieves, on her own monsters flung;
tgt_text.728: and wails her offspring hurled to lurid Orcus by the bolt of Jove :
tgt_text.729: nor does the scorching flame consume Mount Aetna laid upon them, nor does the vulture ever quit the liver of the lustful Tityus, assigned as vengeful warder of the guilty wretch:
tgt_text.730: the amorous Pirithos three hundred chains confine.
tgt_text.731: From his thunder we believe that Jupiter in heaven is king.
tgt_text.732: Augustus shall be deemed a Deity on earth when Britons and dread Parthians are added to his sway.
tgt_text.733: What ! have Crassus' soldiers deigned to live degraded husbands of barbarian wives?
tgt_text.734: and,-shame on the Senate and our altered ways !-has Marsian or Apulian brave, for getting sacred shields and Roman name and dress, and Vesta's never-dying flame, grown old in pay of marriage kin1 under a Persian king, while Rome is safe, and Jove's great temple too ?
tgt_text.735: This had the wary mind of Regulus foreseen when he refused the proffered terms, vile in themselves and fraught with mischief for the time to come, unless the captive youth, with none to pity, died.
tgt_text.736: I've seen, he said, the Roman eagles hung in Punic shrines, and weapons from our soldiers wrung without a blow:
tgt_text.737: I've seen the arms of citizen bound fast behind a freeman's back, and gates2 thrown open wide, and fields our arms once spoiled now tilled again!
tgt_text.738: A soldier ransomed by gold will return, forsooth, a braver man !
tgt_text.739: You only add the loss of money to the foul disgrace:
tgt_text.740: as wool when stained with dye will ne'er regain the colour lost, so sterling worth when ousted once cares not to take its place in baser breast.
tgt_text.741: When stags set free from tangled nets show fight, then he'll be brave who once has yielded to the treacherous foe, and in a second war that man shall crush the Punic hosts, who on his pinioned arms " has felt the thongs, the coward!
tgt_text.743: He, knowing not how life to win, has mixed up peace with war.
tgt_text.747: higher raised by Italy's base fall!
tgt_text.748: 'Tis said he (i.e., Regulus) put aside his wife's chaste kiss and little sons' good-bye, as being a Roman citizen no more, and with his purpose stern, fixed on the ground a hero's gaze, while striving to confirm the Senate's wavering mind by counsel never given before, and hasting forth to noble exile from the midst of weeping friends.
tgt_text.749: And yet he knew full well what cruelties the torturer prepared:

tgt_text.759: The grown-up maiden loves to learn the Ionic dance, and trains herself in all coquettish arts, and from her very cradle medi tates unholy loves :
tgt_text.760: then by and bye she -seeks for younger suitors at her husband's board, nor does she pick and choose the man to whom to grant a hurried and forbidden joy, when lights are out:
tgt_text.761: but when she's called she rises up before her partner's face and with his full consent, whether it be a bagman that invites her, or the captain of some Spanish ship-the costly buyer of her foul disgrace.
tgt_text.762: It was not youths from parents such as these that dyed the sea with Punic blood and slew the great Antiochus and Pyrrhus too, and dreaded Hannibal:
tgt_text.763: but the manly sons of rustic soldiers, inured to trench the soil with Sabine spades, and cut and carry fagots till their rigid mother said "enough," what time the sun reversed the mountain shades, and loosed the yoke from wearied kine, bringing sweet even tide with parting car.

tgt_text.787: For once lay cares aside, and as a private citizen cease to be worried, lest the public suffer aught:

tgt_text.810: and thou, sweet lyre, that know'st so well to send forth sound from seven strings, in olden times not tuneful nor in favour, but now a welcome guest at tables of the rich and at the temple feasts, sing strains to which fair Lyde may incline her stub born ear, who like a " three-year-old" sports in the fields with bounding step, and shrinks from touch of man, not knowing marriage joys, and yet unripe in age.
tgt_text.811: Thou hast power to lead the tigers and the woods in company;
tgt_text.812: thou canst stop the course of rapid streams:
tgt_text.813: by reason of thy soothing strains, did Cerberus, the sentinel of that Infernal hall, give way, although a hundred serpents guard the monster's head, and fetid breath and bloody gore flow from his three-tongued mouth.

tgt_text.917: A better life the nomad Scythians lead, whose wag gons drag their shifting homes from place to place, as is their wont;
