tgt_text.1173: Now neither robes of Coan tint, nor gems of brilliant hue, restore to you the days which fleeting Time has put aside and lodged in musty Calendars.
tgt_text.1177: What is there now of Lyce left, that charm ing Lyce, who breathed forth love, who stole my heart and soul away and made me quite beside myself "-once a form with beauty blessed, next Cinara herself, well known to all, and graced with every winning way ?
tgt_text.1178: But to Cinara the Fates gave years both few and brief, to keep alive long while old Lyce, matching the record of the dotard crow;
tgt_text.1179: that ardent youths might see, with laughter loud, the once bright torch to ashes wasted quite.
tgt_text.1180: Augustus, greatest of chiefs where'er the sun lights up the habitable globe, what zealous care of Senate or of Roman people can ever hope by honours adequate to hand your virtues down to distant times, by carvings on memorial stone or lasting annals of the State ?
tgt_text.1181: Your might in war Vindelic hosts, free heretofore from Latin rule, have lately learned to feel.
tgt_text.1182: For valiant Drusus with your veterans has crushed the bold Genauni, savage race, and Breuni swift in flight, and levelled to the ground their castles perched on giddy Alpine heights, with slaughter more than double what they dealt:
tgt_text.1183: then, later on, the elder Nero fought a stubborn fight, and, with your fortune's star, subdued the giant Raetia wondrous sight to see, with what destruction in the fray of Mars he over came those hearts that to a freeman's death were pledged :
tgt_text.1184: just such as when the south winds lash the " tameless " waves, -the Pleiads shining through the riven clouds :
tgt_text.1185: untiring he to scourge the foe's brigades and through the midst of fires to urge his furious steed :
tgt_text.1186: so rolls the bull-formed Aufidus, which drains the kingdom of Apulian Daunus, when it roars in flood and threatens devastation, vast and wide, to the well cultured fields, as Claudius destroyed the steel-clad lines of the barbarian host with mighty shock, and mowing down from front to rear he strewed the ground with dead, victor with little loss, you giving troops and counsel and your favouring gods.
tgt_text.1187: For just three lustra after Alexandria had humbly opened wide to you her harbours and her empty halls, kind Fortune brought a happy issue to the war, and to your past campaigns has added glory, and the wished-for wreath.
tgt_text.1188: You the Cantabrian, never tamed before, the Mede, the Indian and the Nomad Scyth, regard with awe, 0 Gracious Guard of Italy and Sovereign Rome.
tgt_text.1189: The Nile who hides his foun tain head, the Danube and the Tigris, swift as arrow's speed, obey you:
tgt_text.1190: and the sea, of monsters full, which roars on coasts of Britain, far away:
tgt_text.1191: the men of Gaul that dread not death, the hardy Spaniard, and the Sygambri, who delight in blood, have sheathed the sword and pay you homage due.
tgt_text.1192: When on my lyre I wished to tell of battles fought and cities sacked, Apollo sternly warned me not to spread my sails on the Etruscan main.
tgt_text.1193: Your Age, 0 Caesar, has to our land brought back abundant crops and to our Jove restored the standards wrenched from haughty Parthian fanes :
tgt_text.1194: and closed the doors of Roman Janus, free from war, and curbed the licence which exceeds due bounds, and stamped out crime, and brought again the virtues of the good old days, by which the Latin name and power of Italy have grown so great, and the Empire's fame and glory spread to rising of the sun from where he sets.
tgt_text.1195: While Caesar guards the State, no civil broil nor violence shall banish our repose, nor passion's rage which forges swords, and, to their misery, sets cities by the ears.
tgt_text.1196: Not those who drink from Danube's depths shall break the Julian laws;
tgt_text.1197: not Getae, nor the Seric hordes, nor faithless Parthians, nor those reared up on banks of Scythian Don.

tgt_text.1199: of Troy, too, and Anchises, and the seed of bounteous Venus.
tgt_text.1200: The Ludi Seculares were not held at the end of each century, as the name would imply, but at irregular in tervals, on the occurrence of some great event, or for the purpose of marking an extraordinary epoch.
tgt_text.1201: The hymn sung on such occasions was called the " Carmen Seculare."
tgt_text.1202: Horace was chosen by Augustus as the " Poet Laureate " at the celebration of the Ludi in B.C. 17 :
tgt_text.1203: and his poem is not unworthy of the great Lyrist, or of the choice made by the Emperor.
tgt_text.1204: These games seem to have been called the Ludi Taren tini, or Terentini, or Taurii, in republican times, but during the Empire the name was changed to Ludi Seculares, or " Century Games."
tgt_text.1205: Their origin is by some ascribed to Valerius Publicola, in 509-8 B.C.
tgt_text.1206: It is said that they were instituted to avert a plague, and that they were held in honour of Dis and Proserpina.
tgt_text.1207: From the time of Valerius Publicola down to Augustus they were held only three times, but there are no data to prove in what year or on what occasion these celebrations took place.
tgt_text.1208: No doubt they were held at this time to give eclat and a sort of national sanction to the move which Caesar had recently made in assuming supreme power, for a second period.
tgt_text.1209: But this celebration by Augustus was very different from those of republican times.
tgt_text.1210: Dis and Proserpine who in former days were the chief Deities were now relegated to the very end of the list of those to whom sacrifices were offered.
tgt_text.1211: The festival was held in summer and continued for three days and three nights.
tgt_text.1212: On the first day, games were held in the Tarentum, a part of the Campus Martius, which, as it was said, had belonged to Tarquinius Superbus, and sacrifices were offered to many of the gods.
tgt_text.1213: The Emperor himself began the solemn part of the proceedings at the second hour of the night by offering three lambs to the Parcae, on three altars specially erected.
tgt_text.1214: The blood of the victims was sprinkled on these and the carcases were burned.
tgt_text.1215: A sort of theatre was constructed in the Tarentum in which festive hymns were sung, and other ceremonies performed, including theatrical pieces. "
tgt_text.1216: During the morn ing of the first day the people went to the Capitol to offer sacrifices to Jupiter;
tgt_text.1217: thence they returned to the Tarentum to sing choruses in honour of Diana and Apollo.
tgt_text.1218: On the second day the noblest matrons assembled on the Capitol, performed supplications, sang hymns to the gods, and visited the altar of Juno.
tgt_text.1219: The Emperor, and the Quindecemviri (who kept the Sibylline books, and who had ordered this celebration) offered sacrifices, which had been before vowed, to the great Divinities.
tgt_text.1220: On the third day Greek and Latin choruses were sung in the sanctuary of Apollo, by three times nine boys and as many maidens of great beauty whose parents were still alive."
tgt_text.1221: These hymns implored the favour of the gods for all the interests of the empire.
tgt_text.1222: One of these at the games of 17 B.C. was the Carmen Seculare of Horace.
tgt_text.1223: In later times there were celebrations in the reigns of Claudius and of Domitian.
tgt_text.1224: The last was that of Philippus, A.D. 248.
tgt_text.1225: The term Epode designated, in later times, a poem in which a shorter verse followed a longer one;
tgt_text.1226: strictly it meant the shorter line only, which was a sort of  or echo of the longer one.
tgt_text.1227: It is thus applied to any of the odes included in this " Liber Epodon," or Liber v. of the Odes.
tgt_text.1228: Horace himself calls these Odes not Epodes but Iambi.
tgt_text.1229: The Epodes seem to have been written when Horace was comparatively young, and about the same time as his earliest Satires.
tgt_text.1230: They have certain characteristics in common with the Satires, such as acerbity and animosity ;
tgt_text.1231: but they do not deal in generalities like the Satires, they delight rather in personalities, as in X. against Maevius, and in IV.
tgt_text.1232: against some man of low birth and upbringing who gave himself airs:
tgt_text.1233: and against Canidia and horrid rites.
tgt_text.1234: No. XI. in praise of country life, and XVI.
tgt_text.1235: deploring the misfortune and the sin of civil war, are of a totally different type.
tgt_text.1236: Most of them would seem to have been written between the battle of Philippi and that off Actium.
tgt_text.1237: O Phoebus, and Diana, sovereign of the woods, bright ornament of heaven, adored and still to be adored, 0 grant what at this sacred time we ask, a time at which the Sibyl's verses have advised that youths and maidens, choice and pure, should sing a hymn in honour of the gods with whom the Seven Hills have favour found.
tgt_text.1238: O bounteous Sun, who with thy glittering car dost usher in the light and hide it too, and who from day to day com'st forth afresh-another, yet the same, nought may'st thou ever see more glorious than Rome.
tgt_text.1239: 0 Ilithyia, kind to make way for timely births, preserve all mothers, whether thou prefer'st Lucina as thy name, or wishest Genitalis.
tgt_text.1240: 0 God dess, rear up for us a race of manly men, and with their aid support the Senate's laws for female wedlock and for marriage rites teeming with offspring, so that a perfect cycle, ten times eleven years, may again bring round the hymns, and again renew the sports with thronging crowds for three bright days and three as pleasing nights.
tgt_text.1241: And you, 0 Fates, truthful to tell what once has been decreed, and what the changeless end confirms, join happy destinies to those already past.

tgt_text.1264: Right gladly will I serve in this and every war for surer hope to gain your favour,-not that my plough may strive and strain, when yoked to more and stronger steers, or that my flocks before the Dog-Star heat may change Apulian for Lucanian 11 runs  nor that my country house may stand in glittering show by lofty Tusculum's Circaean walls.
tgt_text.1265: Enough and more your bounty has enriched me;

tgt_text.1267: Happy is he, who far from business cares, like men in early days, tills with his steers his fathers' fields, from every usurer free:
tgt_text.1268: nor as a soldier is he startled by the brawling trumpet note ;
tgt_text.1269: nor as a trader does he dread an angry sea;
tgt_text.1270: he shuns the Courts of Law, and the proud portals of citizens in power.
tgt_text.1271: And so he either weds the lofty poplar to the saplings of the vine ;
tgt_text.1272: or in sequestered Vale surveys his herds of cattle as they roam :
tgt_text.1273: or lopping with his knife the useless boughs inserts more thriving grafts ;
tgt_text.1274: or in clean jars he stores the honey from the combs withdrawn;
tgt_text.1276: or when the Autumn has from the soil put forth its head with mellow fruit adorned, how he delights to pluck the pears he grafted, and cull the grape that rivals purple dye, with which your service to reward, Priapus, and yours, father Silvanus, who the sacred land marks guard.
tgt_text.1277: Sometimes he's pleased to lie beneath an aged holm, sometimes upon the soft and matted grass.
tgt_text.1278: Meanwhile the water in deep channels flows:
tgt_text.1279: in the woods the birds send forth their varied cries, and fountains murmur with their welling rills, which light and gentle slumber may invite.
tgt_text.1280: But when the winter time of thundering Jove collects its snows and showers, either with many a dog on this side and on that he drives the furious boars to the opposing toils, or sets his wide-meshed nets with polished poles, snares for the greedy thrush;

tgt_text.1284: and drawing from the well-cleansed cask the wine of this year's growth, prepares a homely meal:

tgt_text.1286: I would not eat with more delight the guinea fowl, nor heathcock from Ionian moor, than olives plucked from richest boughs or sorrel plant that loves the meads, and mallows good for sickly frames, or lamb at Terminalia slain, or kid just rescued from the ravening wolf.

tgt_text.2948: The Epistles are universally acknowledged to be the most perfect in diction, in metre, in style, and in polish, of all the writings of Horace.
tgt_text.2949: Most of them, if not all, were written, it would seem, in his more mature years when his great practice in composition had prepared him for his highest effort.
tgt_text.2950: The train of thought is that of a refined and educated man, conscious of his powers, and not afraid to declare his opinions, and submit them to the judgment of the world.
tgt_text.2951: The Epistles abound in excellent matter, and are especially conspicuous for their high moral tone.
tgt_text.2952: They have been called 11 the poetry of manner and society," and justly so.
tgt_text.2953: They treat of difficult social and personal affairs with rare discrimination and consummate tact, and give token of greater seriousness and calmer reflection in coming to conclusions than his other works afford.
tgt_text.2954: One sees throughout them the same Horatian characteristics as have been met with in the Odes, the Epodes, and the Satires his patriotism, his love of the country, his admiration of virtue, and his detestation of all that is mean, ignoble, or snobbish;
tgt_text.2955: his advocacy of moderation in all things, and his condemnation of the follies, the extravagance, and the lusts and luxuries of his day, are clearly read between the lines" in his Epistles.
tgt_text.2956: These Epistles are not Satires, but they serve an equally good purpose.
tgt_text.2957: It has been said that while the Satires show what is wrong, the Epistles teach what is right.
tgt_text.2958: Thus they are, in one sense, a continuation and a filling out of the Satires, but are more concerned with individual men, and special subjects and incidents.
tgt_text.2959: The masculine good sense which is found in the Satires makes itself as conspicuous in the Epistles, and renders them as instructive and as appreciable to the reader of to-day as if they were written by a modern author not far removed from our times.
tgt_text.2960: In fact, they are human and cosmopolitan.
tgt_text.2961: They are more free than the Satires from obscure allusions, and their teaching goes at once to the understanding and the heart.
tgt_text.2962: The poet is the same " dear old Horace " with whom, after two thousand years have held his ashes in the urn, we still can chat, and laugh, and sometimes almost weep with him in his more pathetic moods.
tgt_text.2963: Horace had a soul for man, his joys, his cares, his woes.
tgt_text.2964: His motto seems to have been
tgt_text.2966: nil humani a me alienum puto.

tgt_text.2976: Some of them have a good deal of the Satiric in them, and some of them a touch of irony, but all of them display much of that bonhomie which marked Horace in all his dealings with his fellow man.
tgt_text.2977: In the Epistles, more than in the Satires, Horace charms our imagination and wins our affec tions.
tgt_text.2978: When he makes any reference to the faults or weak nesses of friends, he does it with a delicate good humour, full of sympathy and tenderness of feeling.
tgt_text.2979: In the Second Book of the Epistles, the subjects are not moral and social, but literary and critical.
tgt_text.2980: In the First, addressed to the Emperor Augustus, the author defends the Classical School of Latin Poetry," combats the idea that age and not real excellence should be the test of poetry, and predicts with confidence that in process of time the national literature would, slowly perhaps but certainly, attain the highest name.
tgt_text.2981: The Second Epistle, to Florus, gives the poet's reasons for abandoning Lyric Composition.
tgt_text.2982: The Third and most famous of these Literary Epistles is that addressed to the Pisos.
tgt_text.2983: It is not known who gave it the title of " Ars Poetica certainly not Horace himself.
tgt_text.2984: Probably it was one of the Scholiasts or one of the early grammarians.
tgt_text.2985: It was evidently not intended as a complete Treatise on the Art of Poetry, but simply as a friendly letter to Piso and his two sons, the elder of whom, it is supposed, was about to venture on the publication of some poetry he had composed.
tgt_text.2986: Horace's " Ars Poetica " simply gives a brief sketch of the Greek Drama, and states the principles of criticism which should be applied to it.
tgt_text.2987: It accords well in subject and treatment with the two Epistles which precede it.
tgt_text.2988: Horace's remarks on some questions of an aesthetic character are marked by his usual independence of judgment and sound common sense.
tgt_text.2989: See Analysis of the poem in Dean Wick ham's edition of Horace.

tgt_text.0: QUINTUS HORATIUS FLACCUS was born on the 8th of De cember, in the year 65, B. c., at Venusium, a town situated between Apulia and Lueania.
tgt_text.1: Although a freedman, his father possessed competent means, and left him a comfortable patrimony on the banks of the Aufidus.
tgt_text.2: To the education of our poet the greatest attention was paid, and no means were spared to endow him with the highest gifts of mental culture.
tgt_text.3: The severe Orbilius was his guide through the realms of Roman literature, for the poets of which he seems to have conceived an early distaste, preferring the more finished and less rugged beauties of the Greek originals, from whose sources he was himself des tined hereafter to draw so largely, and with such distin guished success.
tgt_text.4: The life of Horace, although spent in the society of those who were most actively mixed up with public affairs, is rather a detail of every-day transactions with the ordinary world, a table-talk of private acts and feelings, than a succession of stirring political relations, exploits, and embarrassments.
tgt_text.5: Whilst engaged in the study of philosophy at Athens, a study which was hereafter to form the ground-work of his literary fame, the assassination of Julius Csar brought on the crisis between the contending interests of Rome.
tgt_text.6: Horace joined the republican party, and attained the rank of a mili tary tribune under Brutus.
tgt_text.7: In whatever light we regard his flight at the subsequent battle of Philippi, it is certain that the disgrace was shared but by too many upon that day, in which the Romans lost their last hopes of freedom, and ex changed public virtue for private luxury and refinement.
tgt_text.8: With the probability that In- small possessions, like those of Virgil, were confiscated to remunerate a soldiery who had fought against their own countrymen, we may fairly suppose that this misfortune first tended to develope the poetical genius of Horace, and that his necessities became a powerful motive for the exertion of talents which had been chastened and ripened by every advantage a fforded by the times.
tgt_text.9: Gradually his powers of wit and repartee, aided perhaps by the propiti atory oblation of little poems "upon occasion," increased his friendships with the great, and introduced him to the intimacy of Mcenas.
tgt_text.10: A friendship of the firmest kind sprang up from what was at first but a distant and patronizing courtesy, and Horace, like Virgil, henceforth became the constant friend and associate of Mcenas, whom lie accompanied upon the most coil fidential missions.
tgt_text.12: C., (for the date is very uncertain,1)
tgt_text.13: Horace followed his patron to Brundusium, where, in company with Cocceius Nerva and Capito, lie was engaged in negotiating a reconciliation between Antony and Augustus.
tgt_text.14: A most amusing description of " travellers' miseries," in the fifth Satire of the first Book, commemorates this event, and gives an entertaining picture of the domestic habits of the wealthier classes at Home during the Augustan age.
tgt_text.15: In accompanying Mcenas in the war against Sextus Pompey, a storm arose, and our poet narrowly escaped being drowned in the Gulf of Velia.
tgt_text.16: Nevertheless, lie volunteered himself as his companion in the expedition that ended with the decisive battle of Actium, an offer which Mcenas, probably out of tenderness to the health of his friend, declined to accept.
tgt_text.17: Mcenas was not a mere complimentary friend, but one of tried liberality.
tgt_text.18: To his kindness our poet was indebted for his villa at Tibur, and to his intercession with Augustus, for a grant of land in the Sabine district.
tgt_text.19: The emperor even offered him the appointment of private secretary to himself, but he declined this honour, as it would have separated him from the frequent society of Mcenas.
tgt_text.20: Augustus bore this refusal in good part, and even personally encouraged our poet to further literary exertions.
tgt_text.21: Alternating between his dwelling on the then healthy Esquiline hill at Rome, and the quieter and more congenial retirement of his villa at Prneste, Horace lived a life of Epicurean enjoyment, not wholly untainted with the vices of the times, but yielding to them rather with the carelessness of a wit, than with the wantonness of a voluptuary.
tgt_text.22: His mode of living at home was simple and unostentatious, but he was by no means insensible to the pleasures of the table, especially in society.
tgt_text.23: He was a kind and indulgent master, and a faithful friend.
tgt_text.24: In fact, an unruffled amiability, re lieved by a keen and well-expressed perception of other men's follies, seems to have been the leading feature in our author's conduct, and the guiding principle of his writings.
tgt_text.25: The beautiful compliment paid to the memory of his father,2 is unsurpassed either as a description of what education ought to be, or as a grateful tribute of filial affection.
tgt_text.26: At the age of fifty-seven, in the year 8, B. C., Horace died suddenly at Rome, having nominated Augustus as his heir.
tgt_text.27: Mcenas died about the same time, almost fulfilling the melancholy prediction of his poet friend, though it is uncertain which first departed from life.
tgt_text.28: In death they were scarcely separated, the remains of Horace being deposited near those of Mcenas, on the Esquiline hill.

tgt_text.1327: HAPPY the man,6 who, remote from business, after the man- ner of the ancient race of mortals, cultivates his paternal lands with his own oxen, disengaged from every kind of usury;

tgt_text.1586: I HAVE ventured to model my version of this Ode, to some extent, on Milton's, " the high-water mark," as it has been termed, " which Horatian translation has attained."

tgt_text.1594: If I have slurred over the Latin, my excuse must be that the precise meaning of the Latin is difficult to catch.
tgt_text.1595: Is Teucer called auspex, as taking the auspices, like an augur, or as giving the auspices, like a god ?
tgt_text.1596: There are objections to both interpretations;
tgt_text.1597: a Roman imperator was not called auspex, though he was attended by an au. spex, and was said to have the auspicia;
